ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course broadened my knowledge of literature that is related to my research. It forced me to examine literature from a more multi-faceted perspective.

Read a lot of great primary texts, with emphasis in placing them in their historical context. Also was helpful to have a class with people from a wide variety of disciplines, which contributed to discussion.
I gained a general knowledge of Renaissance texts and culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I wish this particular course was a year long. I would have liked to spend more time in the texts.

Strengths: great reading list, great instructors, good participants Weaknesses: Discussion was somewhat scattered at points Improved: Focus on specific passages, questions, etc to try to drill down on one aspect of the books

The course was useful as it exposed me to a broad number of topics. This is important, and since the final paper was not a term paper it was adapted to a general study, so I found the homework assignments to be appropriate for an interdisciplinary class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! If nothing else, this course broadens the intellectual discourse.

Yes, I would recommend someone take this course. It gives the students great exposure to some wonderful primary texts from the Renaissance, as well as access to professors who can put them in their contexts.
Yes, if they want a general awareness of Renaissance culture and literature.
